title: Caretaker Uses Facility Supplies for Personal Use
vignette: A maintenance worker takes logs from the institution's wood stock to use in his personal fireplace at home. What compensation, if any, is required?

options.text: He must repay the value of the wood plus a penalty surcharge for the misuse of institutional property.
No penalty is required because the value was small and it was for personal warmth.

title: Earmarked Project Funds Accidentally Spent
vignette: Money earmarked for a specific charity project falls into a general household wallet and is spent on groceries. Once noticed, what repayment formula applies?

options.text: The person must replace the amount plus a penalty surcharge as soon as the error is noticed.
They only need to repay the principal value that was spent.

title: Unauthorized Use of a Designated Asset
vignette: An animal designated for a charity auction was ridden briefly for fun before being brought to the event.

options.text: This unauthorized use constitutes a misuse of assets requiring compensation.
Since the animal was unharmed and returned, no additional payment is necessary.

title: Using Surplus Institutional Fabric for Personal Projects
vignette: Seamstresses making uniforms use surplus fabric that they believe is scrap but actually belongs to the institution. It was an honest mistake. What must they do?

options.text: They must reimburse the institution for the value of the fabric, plus a surcharge.
They should just return the finished clothing without any extra cost.

title: Using a 'Facility-Only' Asset for a Personal Task
vignette: A farmer forgets that his ox was pledged for a ceremonial display and uses it briefly to plough a private field. Is a misuse penalty owed?

options.text: Yes, he owes a penalty for the unauthorized use of a designated asset.
No penalty is required if the use was accidental, brief, and caused no harm.

title: Institution's Resources Mistakenly Used for Public Event
vignette: An institution's catering supplies are mistakenly distributed at a public town feast.

options.text: The community should collectively repay the value of the supplies, plus a fifth.
Repayment should be waived since it benefited the entire community and was a mistake.

title: Using a Canceled Donation
vignette: A donor privately cancels a pledged piece of equipment, but the charity's staff—unaware of the cancellation—use it in a public demonstration. Are the staff liable for misuse?

options.text: No misuse occurred, since the equipment was no longer formally donated property.
The staff are liable because they believed it was donated property and used it as such.

title: Wages Mistakenly Paid from Restricted Funds
vignette: A treasurer accidentally pays contractors from a restricted capital project fund instead of the general payroll account. How is the error rectified?

options.text: The workers must return the money so it can be reissued from the correct account to maintain accounting integrity.
Let the workers keep the money; the institution can simply adjust its internal books.

title: Donated Materials Mixed with General Stock
vignette: Wood donated for a specific building project gets mixed in with the general lumber supply.

options.text: To be safe, the entire pile must be treated as designated for the special project.
Estimate the amount and set aside an equivalent portion for the project.

title: Personal Use of a Decommissioned Ceremonial Item
vignette: Someone legally buys a ceremonial bowl from a museum's decommissioned collection by paying its appraised value, then serves soup in it at home. Is this permitted?

options.text: Permitted; once legally purchased and decommissioned, it is personal property.
It is still disrespectful to use a formerly ceremonial item for a mundane purpose.

title: Partners Profit from Sale of Restricted Asset
vignette: Several investors sell an officially restricted historical artifact and split the proceeds. Who owes the misuse penalty—everyone, or only the partner who arranged the sale?

options.text: Each partner who profited must pay a penalty according to their share.
Only the partner who initiated the sale is liable for the penalty.

title: Unknowingly Purchasing Restricted Assets
vignette: A buyer purchases goods from a seller, unaware that they are restricted assets belonging to a charitable institution.

options.text: Once informed, the buyer must return the items or pay their value to the institution, plus a penalty.
The buyer is exempt from any penalty since they acted in good faith.

title: Continued Misuse After Partial Repayment
vignette: A person begins paying back a penalty for misusing a restricted item but continues to use it before the balance is cleared. Is further use allowed?

options.text: Further use is prohibited until the penalty is fully paid.
The partial payment allows for continued partial use.

title: Staff Pocketing Office Supplies
vignette: Office staff take small amounts of premium office supplies (e.g., nice pens, stationery) home for personal use, considering it an informal perk.

options.text: They must reimburse the company for the supplies and face disciplinary action.
Taking small, inexpensive items as an informal perk is acceptable.

title: Misuse of Institutional Property Discovered Years Later
vignette: Years after using a restricted institutional asset for a personal project, someone learns it was never decommissioned and was still considered institutional property.

options.text: They must pay the misuse penalty even years later.
It's too late; a statute of limitations should apply to such a minor, unintentional violation.
